Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Steve Nash scored 28 points and had eight assists as the Dallas Mavericks won a franchise-record eighth straight road game, 112-106, over the Seattle SuperSonics.
article.headline: Nash's perfect first quarter jump-starts Mavs
article.linkText: Close to home, Nash puts on a show as Mavs trip Sonics
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- Steve Nash of the Dallas Mavericks had his own fan club at the Key Arena.
Nash

"My home town is not very far away," Nash said after scoring 28 points to lead the Mavericks to their franchise-record eighth straight road victory, 112-106 over the Seattle SuperSonics on Tuesday night. Nash, who became the first Canadian All-Star last weekend in Philadelphia, had 15 points and went 4-for-4 from 3-point range in the opening quarter when the Mavericks shot 72.7 percent (16-for-22) and scored 39 points. More than 400 youth basketball players from British Columbia attended the game and chanted Nash's name. Nash is from Victoria, B.C., which is about 125 miles northwest of Seattle. "It felt good to have a lot of support," said Nash, who came out of the locker room after the game and talked to his young fans. Nash made five 3-pointers and shot 9-for-15. He was 5-for-5 in the first quarter. "That wasn't necessarily by design," Nash said of his start. Nash had some admirers on the Sonics' bench, too. "He's the X factor," Seattle coach Nate McMillan said. "He's a very good point guard and he does a lot of things for that team. You know he creates his own shot, he creates shots for his teammates and he keeps pressure on you by pushing the ball up in transition. He's like a waterbug." Juwan Howard and Dirk Nowitzki each had 21 points for Dallas. Gary Payton scored 10 of his 17 points in the final quarter, but it wasn't enough to prevent the Sonics' fourth loss in their last five home games. Rashard Lewis scored 25 points and Brent Barry 20 for Seattle. Dallas coach Don Nelson and Payton were on the winning West side in Philadelphia. "My strategy worked on Gary," Nelson said. "During the All-Star game, we had a practice and I knew we were going to play Seattle. So I had Gary demonstrate taking a charge. I had the other 11 players and the four assistant coaches grab a medicine ball, run the length of the floor and he took 15 straight charges. I wanted to wear him out when we came in here." The Mavericks went ahead to stay, 100-98, on Nowitzki's 3-pointer with 3:58 left, and Michael Finley added two free throws after being fouled by Lewis. Lewis hit an 18-footer over Nowitzki with 2½ minutes to go to cut the Dallas lead to two before the Mavericks' Eduardo Najera grabbed an offensive rebound after a miss by Nowitzki and put the ball in the basket. Seattle's Desmond Mason cut the score to 104-102 on a driving layup with 1:46 to go before Howard made two critical baskets, a 16-footer with 2:07 to go and a putback with 1:23 on the clock to give Dallas a 108-102 lead. Lewis and Mason missed 3-point tries for the Sonics in the final minute. "We don't get nervous down the stretch," Nowitzki said. "We come up with big plays. The pressure is on the home team. It's fun to play on the road." The Mavericks went on a 14-0 run, with Nash and Nowitzki hitting 3-pointers, to take an 80-71 lead with 5:20 to go in the third quarter. The Sonics went 4½ minutes without a field goal before Lewis sank a 12-footer with 4:27 left. The Sonics led 63-61 at halftime, going ahead at 58-56 on a 3-pointer by Barry with 2:08 to play. Barry added two free throws and rookie Vladimir Radmanovic hit a 3-pointer for Seattle in the final 1:38.

Game notes
The Mavericks came into the game leading the NBA in scoring with an average of 104.9 points per game, but were last in the league in points given up with 101.1 per game. ... Mavericks owner Mark Cuban and Sonics owner Howard Schultz had a long talk on the court before the game. ... Dallas beat the Sonics for the fifth time in seven games.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
